title: New way to tap the creativity of our young scientists
text:
“So, there is a real gap between giving them money and giving them the opportunity to do their own thing early on," says Hill, who served many years on both the Research Committee and the Health Advisory Committee of Australia’s National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC).

Highly attuned to the vagaries of research funding, he devised a novel scheme to make outstanding young researchers semi-independent.

Then he implemented it in collaboration with Emeritus Professor James Angus, former dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Dentistry and Health Sciences at Melbourne University, and Professor Robin Marks, a dermatologist and world leader in skin cancer prevention.

Our aim was to find a way to encourage, facilitate, and accelerate the process of early flowering. — Professor David Hill

The scheme buys freedom for young researchers to explore their own original hypotheses while they are at work.

It gives young researchers funding in the form of a grant and their laboratory they join must agree to allow them to spend at least 50 per cent of their working time developing their own ideas and testing them.

It's a win-win, since a laboratory's reputation is enhanced by the work done by its researchers.

"Our aim was to find a way to encourage, facilitate, and accelerate the process of early flowering," says Hill.

“It’s akin to football, when things are getting desperate and, despite a well-rehearsed team plan, the coach says to a young brilliant recruit, ‘Just play your own game,'" he says.

The scheme is unique in medical research in Australia and perhaps internationally. Now there are plans to expand it, which is why Hill was contacting AFR Weekend.

Advertisement

He, Angus and Marks are on the board of the Jack Brockhoff Foundation, known in Melbourne as JBF, which provides research grants for medicine and other good causes.

In 2016, they switched the focus of the medical grants from funding senior researchers to funding projects for young researchers. Since then, JBF has awarded 36 ‘Early Career Research Grants’.

“These have been very well received and we’ve had some very encouraging letters from heads of institutes saying this hits a sweet spot in developing our young talent," says Hill.

“Our only regret is that we attract far more high-quality applications than JBF can afford to fund. Our budget for the scheme is $700,000 per annum.

Professor Robin Marks

Hill wants potential philanthropists – who often have difficulty assessing the worthiness of an enterprise in need of support – to know about this scheme, which could spend at least $1 million a year without wasting a cent.

“The foundation is willing to share access to as yet unfunded, high-quality applicants with no financial benefit to JBF. We have some excellent proposals waiting to be funded.

“Early bibliometric data shows our young grantees are generally making a substantial scientific impact already – well above world averages for their fields. A few are doing spectacularly better.

“Most already have a field-weighted citation index equivalent to those who have spent their careers in the field worldwide.”

Some, like Dr Ryan Cross, are three times more highly cited. Cross describes receiving a JBF grant in 2016 as emotionally massive.

Advertisement

'Early validation'

“Here was an external organisation providing validation that you think creatively, that you have promise. In academia this is rare because most of the time you apply for grants, you try to get published and your ego is constantly bruised.

“This early validation gives you confidence in yourself and your research.”

Cross, who does research into brain cancer at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute in Melbourne, says other recipients say this too.

“These grants give us the assurance and the flexibility to take bold, exciting new ideas forward, rather than sitting on them worrying that we have not been in science long enough to know whether they are novel and new or old and disproven.”

I could feel their struggle and I wanted to make a difference. — Dr Ryan Cross, JBF grant recipient

The $110,000 he received over two years gave him a direct experience of the non-linear nature of scientific discovery. The original idea, for which he received the grant, still hasn’t worked.

But in the process of investigating it, he developed a technology which has far greater potential. This has seen him become a primary investigator in more than $720,000 in further funding from foundations such as Cure Brain Cancer Foundation and Financial Markets Foundation for Children.

His technology allows for the exploration of many new ways of targeting brain cancer using immunotherapy.

This therapy takes blood from a patient and repurposes its cancer-fighting immune cells. Then it returns these cells to the patient where they attack their own tumours.

Advertisement

It works extremely well in some cancers and now the race is on to make it effective in brain cancer too.

Earlier, when Cross was doing his PhD at the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre in Melbourne, he often worked weekends and would mill around chatting to cancer patients.

“I could feel their struggle and I wanted to make a difference. So, I moved from basic biology to an area where it may be possible to make a fast impact on their lives.

“Then I met a brilliant young neurosurgeon who said her patients have no therapies and that I should direct my efforts to brain cancer.”

The quality is there, the need is there, and if this could be translated to other areas of science too, we would welcome it. — Professor James Angus

Cross threw himself into it. “My focus is creating something that can translate into the clinic and I now dedicate all my energies and resources to this.”

As to his original idea, Cross, 31, says, “It’s not a dead end, I’ll circle back to it.”

Professor Angus, a past chairman of the grants committee of the NHMRC, says JBF grants give researchers an opportunity to show how good they are by winning further grants, by getting promotion, by their outputs and maybe by ideas that go onto commercialisation.

“We will keep tracking them over the next decade or two and I’d be surprised if most did not become outstanding scientists.”

For Angus, the scheme has echoes of “the Friday afternoon experiment” which once ran at Melbourne’s Florey Institute.

Advertisement

It was a free space for young researchers to investigate lateral, fresh ideas that had shot off from a solid piece of funded research they were working on.

“It allowed them to have a go,” says Angus,

“Now that we have been doing the JBF grants through three or four cycles, we have confidence that we are picking the right people. The quality is there, the need is there, and if this could be translated to other areas of science too, we would welcome it.

“While JBF grants are restricted to Victoria, we would love for other states to take this up in some way.”

Conditions of entry

So how does it work?

Applicants must have graduated with a PhD within the previous three years and their salary must be certain.

They need to propose an idea that is genuinely original and not shaped by their laboratory head. They also need to identify an unconflicted referee to provide an assessment of their project, and their employing institution has to guarantee 50 per cent of their time to work on it.

Successful candidates receive up to $70,000 per year for up to two years, which allows them to ‘own’, manage and publish a piece of research.

A great admirer of David Hill, Angus says, “The scheme was David’s idea, and we have a wonderful application form which he almost single-handedly wrote.

"I’ve seen a lot of application forms in my time and it is the simplest. It asks the right questions, it is spare and not deluged by words. It ends by simply asking 'and what is your last pitch?'”

Jill Margo is an adjunct associate professor at the University of NSW, Sydney.
description: Rather than encouraging the crazy, brilliant ideas of young scientists, we block them. Here's a smart scheme to set this youthful inspiration free.
